headline: Ultra-cheap safari deals often have significant hidden trade-offs
summary: Safari packages advertised at $100-150/day typically involve compromises: shared minibuses with 6-8 passengers, accommodations outside parks (adding 1-2 hours transit daily), rigid itineraries, rushed game drives, and limited guide quality. While some budget options deliver genuine value, deals that seem too good often result in disappointing experiences.

assumptions.text: Park fees, fuel, and basic operations create a minimum cost floor around $180-250/day.
Vehicle type, group size, and accommodation location significantly impact experience.
Guide expertise is the single biggest factor in safari satisfaction.

gains: Still see wildlife (animals don't check budgets)
losses: Crowded vehicles with limited photo angles
Rigid schedules missing best wildlife times
Long transit times from budget lodges

change_conditions: If deal includes private vehicle and inside-park stays, it may be legitimate value.
If operator has verified reviews mentioning guide names, quality may be consistent.
If you're young, flexible, and purely price-focused, trade-offs may be acceptable.
If this is a once-in-a-lifetime trip, investing more significantly improves experience.
